messages.author: tony
messages.text: Is this pretty quick?  I.e., will it be annoying to run this on developer machines or should it be behind a flag that the buildbot uses?

On 2009/07/15 01:19:15, tony wrote:
> Is this pretty quick?  I.e., will it be annoying to run this on developer
> machines or should it be behind a flag that the buildbot uses?

It took half a second on my Mac Book Pro when running the entire test suite. I put it behind the verbose flag.

messages.author: ojan
tony
messages.text: You shouldn't need the #! line for library classes.

messages.author: tony
messages.text: Nit: Can you document these args?

messages.author: tony
messages.text: Nit: Instead of a comment, use a docstring (i.e., """Get the results for the results.json file.""").

messages.author: tony
messages.text: It looks like this could just be a set that can be initialized from the self._failures list.

messages.author: tony
messages.text:
So for each test, you want to keep track of the result and time.  Can you make a small class that has a result and time?  You can even declare the class in the method.

class ResultAndTime:
  time = 0
  result = "N"

messages.author: tony
messages.text:
Here's a simplification:
failures = [failure.__class__ for failure in self._failures[test]]

if test_failures.FailureCrash in failures:
  return "C"
elif test_failures.FailureTimeout in failures:
  return "T"
...

messages.author: tony
messages.text: Maybe just get the max out of times and compare to 1sec?

messages.author: tony
messages.text: Should this 1 be a constant?
